review.title: Bandit-Based Model Selection for Deformable Object Manipulation
review.abstract: We present a novel approach to deformable object manipulation that does not rely on highly-accurate modeling. The key contribution of this paper is to formulate the task as a Multi-Armed Bandit problem, with each arm representing a model of the deformable object. To "pull" an arm and evaluate its utility, we use the arm's model to generate a velocity command for the gripper(s) holding the object and execute it. As the task proceeds and the object deforms, the utility of each model can change. Our framework estimates these changes and balances exploration of the model set with exploitation of high-utility models. We also propose an approach based on Kalman Filtering for Non-stationary Multi-armed Normal Bandits (KF-MANB) to leverage the coupling between models to learn more from each arm pull. We demonstrate that our method outperforms previous methods on synthetic trials, and performs competitively on several manipulation tasks in simulation.
histories: Presented at the Workshop on the Algorithmic Foundations of Robotics, 2016, San Francisco, CA
review.COMMENTS: Presented at the Workshop on the Algorithmic Foundations of Robotics, 2016, San Francisco, CA

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: One of the most important challenges in terms of the deformability of objects is the difficulty of modeling and simulating them. Most simulation methods are able to circumvent this challenge by applying the specific manipulation mechanisms.

sections.heading: 4 Bandit-Based Model Selection
sections.text: The primary difficulty in solving (4) directly is that the effectiveness of a given model in minimizing errors is unknown. (It may be that no model in the set produces the optimal option, but this does not prevent a model from being useful. In particular, the benefit of a model may change from one task to another and from one configuration to another, as the deformable object changes shape and moves in and out of contact with the environment. We start by defining the benefit around (t) by considering the space of a model as the expected improvement of the task error when the model m is used to generate a robot command in due time. If we know which model has the greatest benefit, we can resolve (4). This leads to a classic exploration-exploitation compromise where we have to explore the space of models in order to learn which is most useful, while at the same time exploiting the knowledge we have gained to define the framework that is already a multiarm (the multiarm).

sections.heading: 5.1 Algorithms for MAB
sections.text: We have tested three algorithms in our experiments, and our extension of KF-MANB, Kalman Filter Based Solution to Non-Stationary Normal Dependent Bandit (KF-MANDB), and our extension of KF-MANB, Kalman Filter Based Solution to Non-Stationary Multi-Arm Dependent Bandit (KF-MANDB).UCB1-Normal Algorithm [16] treats each arm (model) as independent, estimating an optimistic Upper Confidence Bound (UCB) for the utility of each model.

sections.heading: 6 Experiments and Results
sections.text: We test our method on three synthetic tests and three deformable object manipulation tasks in the simulation. The synthetic tasks show that the principles we apply to estimate the coupling between models are reasonable, while the simulated tasks show that our method is effective in performing deformable object manipulation tasks.

sections.heading: 6.1 Synthetic Tests
sections.text: For the synthetic tests, we set up an underupdated system that is representative of the manipulation of a deformable object with configuration y-Rn and control input x-Rm, so that m < n and y-Rm = Jx-Rm. To construct the Jacobian of this system, we start with J = [Im · m 0 (n − m) × m] and add uniform noise drawn from [− 0,1, 0,1] each element of J. The system configuration starts at [10.. 10] T with the target configuration specified to the origin. Error is defined as B (t) = y (t), and the desired direction in which the system is moved at each time step is y (t) = y (t). These tasks have no obstacles or strain, i.e. β, λ, and q ² max, o are not used. Instead of setting the utility noise scale, we use an andres (J + 10) filter method (J = 0,00t).

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: Our formulation enables the application of existing MAB algorithms to deformable object manipulations and introduces a novel utility size to measure how useful a model is in performing a given task. We have also presented Kalman Filtering for Non-stationary Multi-arm Normal Dependent Bandits (KF-MANDB) to use the coupling between dependent bandits to learn more from each arm pull. Our experiments show how to successfully perform several interesting tasks for rope and cloth with our method. One remarkable result we observe is that finding and exploiting the best model is less important than avoiding bad models over long periods of time. In all experiments, UCB1-Normal never leaves its initial exploration phase, but it is able to successfully perform each task. We believe this is due to the fact that many models are able to provide commands that point a positive product with correct direction of motion.

sections.heading: 8 Acknowledgements
sections.text: This work was partially supported by NSF grants IIS-1656101 and IIS-1551219. We thank Calder Phillips-Grafflin for his help with Bullet.

While there is work that frames robust trajectory selection as a MAB problem [8], we are not aware of any previous work which either 1) frames model selection for deformable objects as a MAB problem; or 2) addresses the coupling between arms for non-stationary MAB problems.

The first approximation we use is a diminishing-rigidity Jacobian [12] which assumes that points on the deformable object that are near a gripper move “almost rigidly” with respect to the gripper while points that are further away move “less rigidly”.
The second approximation we use is an adaptive Jacobian [13] which uses online estimation to approximate J(q).

UCB1-Normal : The UCB1-Normal algorithm [16] treats each arm (model) as independent, estimating an optimistic Upper Confidence Bound (UCB) for the utility of each model.

KF-MANB : The Kalman Filter Based Solution to Non-Stationary Multi-arm Bandit (KF-MANB) algorithm [20] uses independent Kalman filters to estimate the utility distribution of each model, and then uses Thompson sampling [19] to chose which model to use at each timestep.

metadata.abstractText: We present a novel approach to deformable object manipulation that does not rely on highly-accurate modeling. The key contribution of this paper is to formulate the task as a Multi-Armed Bandit problem, with each arm representing a model of the deformable object. To “pull” an arm and evaluate its utility, we use the arm’s model to generate a velocity command for the gripper(s) holding the object and execute it. As the task proceeds and the object deforms, the utility of each model can change. Our framework estimates these changes and balances exploration of the model set with exploitation of high-utility models. We also propose an approach based on Kalman Filtering for Non-stationary Multi-armed Normal Bandits (KF-MANB) to leverage the coupling between models to learn more from each arm pull. We demonstrate that our method outperforms previous methods on synthetic trials, and performs competitively on several manipulation tasks in simulation.
